2.author: toddegreene
2.body:
Yes. 
After briefly looking at your post history, I have a comment about weight. Prior to AML diagnosis, my son was a D1 recruited athlete in two sports. He went from 195lb/88kg, to 138lb/63kg. It took over two years before he gained any weight, and  another year to gain significant weight. By year 5 he was back to his original weight. He explained that his brain wanted food, but after 2 or 3 bites he was full. Then one day his appetite was back. 

As soon as he was able, went to the gym and started working with a trainer to build strength and endurance. It was a slow process. He's back to playing sports recreationally. 

He's also been seeing a psychologist from his cancer center since his diagnosis. It helps to be able to talk to someone who isn't friends or family. 

How are you doing overall?

7.author: Zorcky-2C
7.body:
I get your point. When we say France, we most likely refers as Metropolitan France (the hexagon only).

But France also has overseas territories (we call it DOM-TOM here). They are also France, has the same laws, same president etc. But they are quite a special case.

France territory has technically borders with Brazil, but since when we say "France" we probably talk about the hexagon only, I would say your affirmation is correct to say.

7.author: Diablo_Lynx
7.body:
The way I see it, what do the people that live next to Brazil say... I can pretty much guarantee none of them say they live in France, and if someone else suggested it to them I think they'd be insulted.

Overseas territories do have their own identity and I think it's disrespectful when the Western world want to gloss over that for the sake of a contentious pub quiz question.

7.author: Zorcky-2C
7.body:
Yep, i've never been here but I'm pretty sure you're right. It's not the same life style and the same culture at all over there, and it's a good thing.

Theses territories are a lot different from metropolitan France. So it doesn't feel like France but on paper it technically is.

But the paper changes lots of things. Like they have the same tax laws, same health insurance, same military protection... and the list goes on.

These people identifies themselves from their regions, yeah. My friends from the Reunion says they are form the Reunion and not from France.
But I guess it's just a way to show that you are proud from your region because we have a region called Bretagne and it is located in metropolitan France. People from this region identifies as Bretons.

They identify themselves from the region they are from, but it doesn't mean they don't identify as a french

7.author: Diablo_Lynx
7.body: I get what you're saying - I'm Scottish, and I identify as Scottish. On paper I'm British, but I'm most definitely Scottish. It's why I think we should refer to places by their own name and their own identity. Colonialism was a terrible thing and the least we can do is respect that these legacy territories are not French /British/ German in anything other than name and inherited infrastructure.

20.author: shucksme
20.body:
Red lining is a concerted effort by the local, state and even federal governments working with banks and other lenders to make it impossible for certain people (in this case, as it was post WWII, blacks and southern European) to purchase a house or own a business outside of a determined area-a containment area. Even if they could afford the loan or even pay cash. An area that may be well known to the general public (grottos) or to a select few who act as a wizard behind the scenes. 

This type of systemic racism (where it is literally built into the definition of how to live in society) would reject people from getting a home or business loan and give them the run around till they gave up. 

I'm from Metro Detroit. We have a very famous red line. 8 mile (as in Eminem). It maybe where the term red line came from (I'd like to know for sure). There was a map that had a red pencil that drew a line from Lake St. Claire along 8 mile to some other road going North/south that boxed the core of Detroit. Along much of 8 mile, to this very day, there is an 8 foot wall that was put up along the neighborhood part (would open up for the main roads) to help keep walkers from exploring north. The wall was put up under the disguise to reduce the sound from the main throughway that 8 mile is. People could travel north all they wanted but they could not live and reduced their ability to work outside of that area. Buses would have their routes not cross those zones and would force people to take connectors increasing the irritation and hassle to reduce the amount of people who would be willing to go outside of those zones. 

Where it all came to a head was the aging car factories would need to build a new factory. But the only places without high density to build a new massive building (many an entire mile long) would be north of Detroit. Metro Detroit. So the old factories would close and the white people would buy new homes near the new factory with the nice schools and parks. But black people were stuck with no jobs, aging housing and schools which means increasing crime. Which brings us to the race riots of 1968. 

These angers boiled in the summer in many cities (Detroit, Atlanta, LA, DC, Baltimore..). Sparked in large by the systemic racism from Vietnam war, assassination of MLK and everything engrained. This is where President Johnson stepped up and kind of addressed the issues. 

My mother remembers National Guard tanks rolling down her street during the riots. Curfews, crime (my grandmother had someone walk into her home to rob to place or worse and she ended up stabbing the guy), police brutality (the number dead on record is not the real number killed as told to me by a guy who was a cop then), fires... All of this led to a mass exodus of whites leaving the city. Because they could. Slowly red lining was dropped (more like expanded). In the 80's crack destroyed what little soul was left in the city as the people left there were victims of the system and trapped in learned helplessness. 

Today it is coming back. The heart of Detroit has always been nice to visit. Now there are more zones that are nice to visit, work and even live in. But it's taken 70 years to turn it around. 

That's just the tip of what red lining is. All for what gain? Noting that it is going on today; maybe not in home loans but certainly in other forms. Take for instance health insurance. 



PBS did an hour segment on Red Lining focusing on Springfield, IL and Dayton, OH. It's also on YouTube. 

https://www.pbs.org/video/redlining-mapping-inequality-in-dayton-springfield-kam44p/


Do you live in a city that was defined this way?

To call it slavery though is half baked at best. I’ll agree though, it’s wrong. I’ve always heard of for profit prisons, but never knew much. I’m gonna look into it and maybe I’ll be more understanding. I enjoy these conversations because a lot of times it’ll open your eyes to a different viewpoint. I’ll disagree on slavery, but agree on for profit prisons and cops needing to clean their shit up. I’ve spent several days in jail myself, and come to find out years later the jailer had a side job with the commissary company. He was fired from jail, or should say resigned, but still pedals commissary. I put $100 in mine when I had to do 5 days, and they never once let me out of the drunk tank. I was told I could shower and brush teeth, but I stayed in the same room all 5 days without either. Transferred the $ to a friend who was in there when I left.  Granted, I felt I deserved to be in there, but should’ve been able to brush my teeth. It’s been nice having this dialect with you, I’ve learned something and don’t blame you for feeling strongly about something. If nobody cared then nobody would care. Please remember not every cop is a piece of shit. Too many are, but many aren’t. And there are insurance companies that will automatically lawyer you up and bail you out if you ever have to shoot someone. USCCA is a little too Republicany-like for me, but still has my back. Good day

24.author: Direct_Indication226
24.body:
It's not lost on me that I'm being pretentious in print.

So if J.P. sounds like some jackass perusing prose as daily dialect then I can at least glean your general intent.

Casting aside the obnoxious charade: 

Do you think anyone could ever be taken seriously if they spoke the way they write?

Why would you begrudge me enjoying wordplay for its own sake?  I just wanted someone witty to do something fun with words and make me laugh with painfully specific word choice.  

Hope y'all enjoy your day. I'll look up this J.P. guy in some clips and see if I can actually utilize context clues to see what your fully intended insult was. Might come back and give ya some props.

Edit: Actually upon further review, no.

I watched his highlight reel and he does the exact opposite of what I was doing.

He doesn't use vocabulary as a weapon at all. He is, however, annoyingly self-assured, but that is where the parallel ends.

My whole point was to succinctly annoy with an economy of words - being efficient with a lexicon and saying the most in the fewest syllables without sacrificing specificity. 

I never thought it sounded like daily colloquial conversation. 

I think you just had to utilize too many resource materials for it to have been a fun exercise for you but plenty of authors enjoy using pedantry as a competitive challenge.

The goal was to progressively amp up the witticisms and creative insults and I was starting slow to build momentum,  so you would've only found the exercise more bothersome the more we jousted.

Good day, stranger.

It's my fault I had you on offense from the jump I was just using basic psychology to get the most number of responses in the hopes that by the law of large numbers someone among the chain would've risen to the affront.

It's the same mentality that dictates that in order to get an answer to a question you have, you're far more likely to get your answer by confidently claiming something false than by asking a question because people far more enjoy correcting others than answering a random question on the internet.

If you don't appreciate the comparison, maybe it's less similar yet still somewhat helpful as a concept to think of how you can leave a piece of furniture by the curb with a "free" sign on it and noone will take it, yet if the sign is switched to one saying "$50" the furniture will be stolen hastily.

People are contrarians.

I just wanted to dally in a dictionary dance.

38.author: lactavistforlife
38.body: That truly depends - if you can prove that you finished high school or at least have a GED, then you're required to work if you want a monthly stipend which is required for things like food, clothing, etc. beyond what the state provides you through the chow hall/quartermaster. Jobs range anywhere from working in the chow hall to in the dorm, on the yard, in the school as a tutor. Alternatively, if you want to further your education you may do so as well. College is provided at no cost in most institutions. Security level is another factor. But yes, jobs are used to break up monotony a lot of times. There's only so many books in the library, and being in your cell/bed will eat you alive if you let it. $12-24 a month is mighty appealing when you don't have anyone on the streets looking out for you.

38.author: firmerJoe
38.body: Thank you for this answer.  So by 12 to 24 a month you mean that the average pay for a day could be 75 cents?  How much could a person possibly make if they just went all out to earn?

38.author: lactavistforlife
38.body: In theory, sure. But your state pay, as it is known, it's based off what you are "classed" as, and hits your account on the Thursday of the first full week. This isn't prorated, it's usually a lump sum. 24 is the current max for state stipend, and that particular pay rate is reserved for things like chaplains assistant, high ranking tutors, the top of the prison job food chain. If you manage to become a referee for some of the sports being played, the recreational coordinator has the option of awarding you an additional .50 per game you referee. The average pay for serving up state food or sitting in class is $18 a month. College students get $20. If you have no job at all, $12 a month. On the opposite side of this coin, if you have someone supporting you, the most you can spend in commissary is $100 a week, which will let you live a fair bit more comfortable than what they give you. The downside? All of your food has to fit inside a 2.4 cubic foot locker box, and you'd be smart to keep your receipts to prove you didn't steal any of it in the likely event that you get searched.

38.author: firmerJoe
38.body: So all of you food storage has to fit into a high school locker.  These numbers may seem unrealistic but I'm sure they are a motivator of some kind.  I'm not sure if you are speaking out of experience or expertise, but does this level of stipend motivate people to do extra work?  Also, what is the rough percentage of prisoners that can rely on no 9ne but themselves?

38.author: lactavistforlife
38.body: Essentially, yes, and to add to the experience, the same mentality that you encountered in high school is the norm, sadly. High school for grown ups, in a nutshell. The level of stipend is often seen as "hey, better than nothing", by most, but it does help things along. A pack of ramen a night at .23 a meal helps with the hunger pains, as some things that are served tend to be less than palatable. I wouldn't go so far as to say it motivates, but it's a bright spot on the otherwise blight ridden piece of fruit which is your life, for however long you're a ward of the state. As for how many persons rely on state pay alone, the population is a microcosm of what you see in the world. You have those who have no one, and then there are persons who are financially independent, and of course everywhere in-between. Illegal gambling, drugs, gang activity, extortion, blackmail... these are all factors which may impact someone's need for state pay/outside support.

38.author: firmerJoe
38.body: Thank you for entertaining my questions.  I am genuinly curious as to the workings of these facilities.  We have a sizable portion of the population serving sentences yet understand so very little about the workings.  Thank you for sharing.

38.author: lactavistforlife
38.body: You are most welcome, I'm happy to share any knowledge that I have with persons who are willing to listen. You're absolutely right, the number of persons who are incarcerated is staggering and what happens in their daily lives is often not discussed. I hope this helps others as well.

51.author: ExasperatedEE
51.body:
You don't have an argument either.

How do you think evolution works? A huge chunk of DNA changes all at once? That kills the animal.

51.author: cosmicmicowavepickle
51.body: Mutation is part of the equation, but not the whole. A mutation is just that: a mutation. It's meaningless on its own. Getting melanoma is a mutation too, but that's not evolution. Evolution requires several other factors in order to happen, and not all situations are the same. Broadly speaking, they're either environmental or behavioral. If you really want to learn, look into how homo sapiens became different from other early hominids. Spoiler: we didn't just mutate and out compete them.

51.author: cosmicmicowavepickle
51.body: Alfred Wallace has some great texts on speciation as well if you're interested. Charles Darwin wasn't the great thinker everyone thinks he is, and there's strong evidence that of Darwin plagiarizing his works when he wrote The Origin of Species. I'm not trying to be combative, but there are some large misconceptions on contemporary understandings of evolution. It's not dependent on mutation, which is why sharks and crocodiles have remained unchanged for millions of years. It's really complicated. Like I said, not the time nor crayons.

51.author: ExasperatedEE
51.body:
> Getting melanoma is a mutation too, but that's not evolution. 

You only say that because melanoma is not a mutation that is beneficial to the species ability to survive.

But that's irrelevant. Evolution is change. Evolution is not "only that change which leads to positive outcomes".

Ever hear of an evolutionary dead end? Mutations can happen which may temporarily benefit a species, but ultimately were a bad direction for it to take. Nonetheless, that is still evolution.

Also, if a mutation occurs, and the animal nevever breeds, that's still part of evolution. That's evolution saying "you're not fit enough to continue your lineage".

You can't have natural selection where only GOOD selections count. Natural selection is the sum of both good and bad. 

> Evolution requires several other factors in order to happen

The ONLY factor required for evolution is that a change makes it more likely for the animal to reproduce. If you reproduce less, the change will propograte less. If you reproduce more it will propogate more.

If a human was born who was immortal, but he never had any kids becuase he was also sterile, that change, no matter how beneficial it would be to mankind, would not spread.

> Spoiler: we didn't just mutate and out compete them.

Except that is exactly what happened. For whatever reason, we out competed them. We had more babies, and they either died off because they didn't breed enough, or because we killed them. And if we killed them it is because evolution made us such that we are inclined to kill those too different from us.

51.author: ExasperatedEE
51.body:
> It's not dependent on mutation, which is why sharks and crocodiles have remained unchanged for millions of years. It's really complicated.

Oh my fucking god.

If it's not dependent on mutation then how do you imagine change occurs?

If the DNA remains identical, the animal will remain identical.

If the DNA changes, that is a mutation.

It's that simple. There is nothing in between. Either it mutates, or it does not. And if it mutates, which it does, something about the animal changes. Maybe that makes it more fit for survival, and that leads it to produce more offspring. If they happens enough, the change becomes ingrained in the species. That's evolution.

>  which is why sharks and crocodiles have remained unchanged for millions of years.

Sharks and crocodiles have remained unchanged because they reached a point where they were very good at doing what they do and any mutations that have occurred in individuals did not result in those individuals out competing the rest of them.

Also saying that sharks have remained unchanged is not correct in the first place. There isn't one species of shark. There are many. 

There are also many different species of crocodiles:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crocodile

You don't even know that crocodiles and sharks are actually many different species, and that crocodile and shark are simply the name for a family of animals that covers many species.

And there are also several species of crocodiles which have died out. Here's one which died out just 4,000 years ago:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mekosuchus

> Historians of science have noted that, while Darwin considered the ideas in Wallace's paper to be essentially the same as his own, there were differences.[122] Darwin emphasised competition between individuals of the same species to survive and reproduce, whereas Wallace emphasised environmental pressures on varieties and species forcing them to become adapted to their local conditions, leading populations in different locations to diverge.

Spoiler: IT'S BOTH.

And also both result from mutations in DNA which get carried forward to future generations.

PS: Perhaps you're confused by "mutations". When I say mutations in DNA I am not just referring to the sort of mutations that occur if DNA breaks. I am referring also to changes that happen when two parents with their different DNA mate and they produce a new offspring with combined DNA that is different from both. A child of two short parents can result in a child who is much taller. These "mutations" can spread to future generations just as easily as random mutations from cosmic radiation might.

51.author: cosmicmicowavepickle
51.body: Your misconceptions might be funny if your arrogance wasn't so astounding. Why other hominids disappeared is still a mystery, but the current theory is a changing environment killed them off. The evidence we have from early human contact is that we interbred with other human species, and most hominids didn't come into contact with us at all. The early human conquest theory is regarded as eurocentric, and relies more on theory than fact.

51.author: ExasperatedEE
51.body:
> hy other hominids disappeared is still a mystery, but the current theory is a changing environment killed them off.

No shit. And if it was their environment then it killed them off because they had not evolved to survive in it, and they did not evolve quickly enough to survive, much like the dinosaurs when the asteroid hit and temperatures dropped worldwide.

> The evidence we have from early human contact is that we interbred with other human species, and most hominids didn't come into contact with us at all.

That's cool, and has nothing to do with the discussion at hand. I do not care why specifically early hominids died off. It is irrelevant in a discussion about what evolution is and how it is all driven by changes in genetics at the lowest level of abstraction.

Animals mate. They combine their DNA. Mutations occur somtimes. Sometimes those mutations or the changes that result from combining their DNA are beneficial. Sometimes they are not. Regardless of whether they are or not, it is still evolution at work. 

To say otherwise is to say it is not gambling if you happen to lose that day at the casino. Futhermore, if you win, but get robbed in the parking lot by someone with a gun at the end of the day, you still gambled.

So early hominids still took part in the process of evolution, even if they were ultimately wiped out because their environment changed, or mankind came along and killed them all. They just didn't evolve in a way which enabled them to survive. Mankind did. The end.

Literally everything that happens to you every day is the END RESULT of billions of years of evolution. So if some dude stabs you in the gut and you die, you died because evolution made people violent, and your genes didn't make you strong enough to survive that encounter.

51.author: cosmicmicowavepickle
51.body:
You seem to be married to the highschool understanding of evolution. You also seem to be unaware of how behavioral patterns are different from genetics. 

You're making fundamental misunderstandings on how the process of evolution works. Where did you learn all this?

51.author: ExasperatedEE
51.body:
> You also seem to be unaware of how behavioral patterns are different from genetics. 

You seem to be unaware that genetics control how our brains are structured and therefore how we think and behave.

Why do you think a squirrel is skittish, while a quokka will hop right up to people?

The answer is because the quokka had no environmental pressure to be afraid of predators. Therefore it is not. And it will not be regardless of whether you take one and raise it outside the safety of that environment. It has no instinct to be afraid, just as we laregly bred fear of people out of dogs and cats by domesticating them.

Also, if you take the same species, like a squirrel, and you place it in two distinct envrionments like the city and the country, it will behave somewhat differently. But guess what? That's also due to evolution. It evolved to be malleable because malleable means a greater chance of survival.

57.author: Dittybopper
57.body: Each key input for our 12 hour cycle was immediately burned once our radio checks had been accomplished. If a key codebook of ours was captured it would only have future key settings in it - nothing compromised.

57.author: EasternShade
57.body:
Nothing compromised... assuming key use ended when it was compromised and the network rotated onto different keys. Same as it would be with the stolen radio in OP.

That's the SOP that they fucked up regardless. They lost a radio, they should have known or assumed they lost a radio, discounted use, and rotated keys. Instead, they kept using compromised keys. Larger stores of keys with more frequent rotations doesn't address that.

57.author: Dittybopper
57.body:
The Ukrainian military SIGINT types were able to use the captured radio 9+ days after it came into their possession. Nine days of knowing everything said on that radio network *because of prolonged key use.* 

I have no clue, and will not assume, what the Orc cryptographic SOP is/was. Can you imagine the wealth of intelligence gained by the Ukrainians by them capturing and monitoring the enemy radio network?

57.author: EasternShade
57.body:
Yep. That's why rotating keys when there's a possibility they've been compromised is important.

How much they gathered depends on the key distribution. It's not too bad if it's strictly regionalized. It's pretty bad if it's a wide distribution.
